That would probably be looking for sense of security, send of control, sense of safety. The most common pattern of individual behaviors emerge for that need. Its more precious to humans that air we breath. e.g. far more people drown because of panic than by loosing all air, or technicality speaking they accelerate the process of drowning because they feel they are loosing control. This emotional need for sense of control is so common because its so deeply necessary for us humans. Look at any human behaviors and that is the most common pattern you will find, a need for control and endless ways we humans try to achieve it. I know you used the word “behavior” in your question, but I will expand on it by saying that techniques are all over the place, but the pattern is found in the principle (humans need to feel they are in control to feel safe, and that is our primary emotional concern.) and therefore most common human behaviors emerge from that emotional need.

Yet, one common natural and basic instinct survived and is still the most common among human behavior and that is “fight or flight” The problem is, humanity has forgotten how to properly react or decide upon said instinct. A lot of the time, we see the bad in people before we see the good. We assume people are selfish, mean, and vindictive before they are good. Essentially, humans assume things about people without good reason. Maybe you're walking down the street, and you hear two people behind you begin laughing. You assume that they're laughing at you, and listen in to their conversation. You hear some words that you associate with yourself, and before you know it, you're whirling around to confront these jerks. Except…they're not, they were actually laughing about something in their life. To them, you're the jerk, and they have a reason. The reason, I assume, that humans assume things is because of their insecurities. They might be insecure about their physical features, their various -isms, ect. I think that we're all insecure, in some shape or form. Even the most confident person may be insecure. Thanks for the A2A!

I am not sure where this fits in, but it was somewhat stunning to me at the time. As a Credentialing Coordinator, part of my job was to get copies of physician licenses when they were renewed and provide copies to all hospitals where the physicians held privileges. I kept contacting the doctors and they all were telling me they had not received their renewals. I decided it was time to contact the medical board to verify that the doctors had renewed and were legally practicing their professions. The answer I got was that they had moved their office and were working out of boxes because the prison was on lockdown. I was told that the State requires all State offices to get furnishings through the prison and because of the lockdown, no furniture was being made or distributed! They were giving verbal provisional renewals until such time as they got furniture and could set the office up for the work they did. It took awhile for me to digest this information and then I had to laugh, thinking that doctors were working without a hard copy of their medical license because some prisoners had misbehaved! I contacted my counter part at hospitals who had been calling for the licenses and some were willing to take my word that I had contacted the medical board and some thought the story was too far out and called the board to get the “facts.”
